acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was deposited in 1932 by Charles R. Kennon. It was made a gift to the Library on December 16, 1980, by Charles R. Kennon, Jr., and Richard R. Kennon of Powhatan, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: These manuscripts are principally the business papers of Major Henry Heth (d.1822), Revolutionary soldier, merchant of Richmond and Manchester, and prominent member of the Federalist party.

Harry Heth, as he signed himself, emigrated from England to Virginia in 1759, settled in Chesterfield County, and engaged in various business and commercial enterprises in and around Richmond, and in Norfolk, until his death in 1822. During the Revolution he served first as captain and later as major in the 1st Virginia Regiment, remaining in the service of the state as a militia officer following the close of the war. From 1789 to 1792 he acted as agent for the sale of publicly owned tobacco. His papers record his activities in this connection and as an agent at various times for provisioning United States troops in Virginia. Heth married Nancy Blair, of Richmond, and lived at or near "Black Heath," the home near Manchester of his brother William, and of later generations of this distinguished family, notably Lieut. Gen. Harry Heth of the Confederate army. Some of the papers here calendared reveal details of Heth's operation of the Black Heath coal pits. Others show his association, as a leader of the Federalist party, with George Washington, John Marshall, and important figures in the administration of John Adams. The bulk of the manuscripts, however, fall in the period from 1790 to 1800, are most numerous in the last years of that decade, and relate chiefly to Heth's numerous business interests. The chronological order of the calendar is interrupted by a group of papers, listed together, which record a dispute (1794-95) between Heth and John W. Hunt, his Norfolk partner in a shipping business. Letters from Harry Heth to various governors have been published in the Calendar of Virginia State Papers. His portrait by St. Memin hangs in the Corcoran Art Gallery.

The Heth Papers contain ca. 4,000 items, 1763-1841, and include letters, accounts, bills, receipts, legal documents, and slavery documents. Among the notable items in the collection are: John Marshall, Opinion in the case of Heth v. Cooper and A.L.S. to Harry Heth. (1793 Nov. 8); James Monroe, Indenture appointing Harry Heth attorney to sell land in Bourbon County, Ky. (1812 Mar. 2); John Edmund Page, A.L.S. to Harry Heth (1804 Aug. 12); John Edmund Randolph, A.L.S. to Harry Heth (1811 Apr. 23); Thomas Mann Randolph, nine A.L.S. to Harry Heth. (1813 June 12, 1814 April. 17, 1815 Jul. 22, 1815 Sep. 17, 1815 Oct. 4, 1815 Dec. 4, 1819 Jan. 3). Richmond, Virginia Return of taxable property in the City of Richmond for the year 1788. 22 pp. 1788. Washington, George (1732-1799) A.L.S. to Wm. Heth, et. al. (1799 May 12).
